{{infobox military conflict |conflict =Action of 23 November 1650 |partof =the [[Franco-Spanish War (1635)]] |image = |caption = |date =23 November 1650 |place =Off [[Cambrils]], [[Catalonia]], [[Spain]] |coordinates = |map_type = |latitude = |longitude = |map_size = |map_marksize = |map_caption = |map_label = |territory = |result =Spanish victoryIsrael p.117Coll/Muñoz p. 226 |status = |combatant1 ={{flag|Kingdom of France|23px}} |combatant2 ={{flagicon|Spain|1506|23px}} [[Habsburg Spain|Spain]] |commander1 ={{flagicon|Kingdom of France|23px}} [[Franco-Spanish War (1635)|Baron de Ligny]]{{POW}} |commander2 ={{flagicon|Spain|1506|23px}} [[Francisco Fernández de la Cueva, 8th Duke of Alburquerque|Duke of Alburquerque]] |units1 = |units2 = |units3 = |strength1 =4 [[galleon]]sCastrillo González p. 241 |strength2 =6 [[galley]]s |casualties1 =4 galleons and their crews capturedColl/Sebastià p. 226
500 soldiers prisoners
4 pieces of artillery taken |casualties2 =Minimum |notes = |campaignbox ={{Campaignbox Franco-Spanish War (1635-1659)}} }} The '''Action of 23 November 1650''' was a minor naval battle between [[Spain]] and [[France]], in which a small Spanish squadron of 6 [[galley]]s commanded by Don [[Francisco Fernández de la Cueva, 8th Duke of Alburquerque|Francisco Fernández de la Cueva, Duke of Alburquerque]], captured an entirety of a French squadron of [[galleon]]s under the [[Franco-Spanish War (1635)|Baron de Ligny]], near [[Cambrils]], during the [[Franco-Spanish War (1635-1659)]]. The French fleet consisted of a galleon of 500 [[Metric ton|ton]]s and 30 [[cannon]]s, 2 of 300 tons with 20 cannons, and the last of 300 tons and 16 cannons. The French fleet was sent filled with provisioneses to help the defenders in the [[Tortosa|Siege of Tortosa]], but the squadron of the [[Francisco Fernández de la Cueva, 8th Duke of Alburquerque|Duke of Albuquerque]], knowing the enemy's plans, intercepted the French by surprise, achieving a complete victory. This case is almost unique in naval history, 6 galleys with 30 guns in total, completely defeated a squadron of four galleons with 86 guns in total, and whose crew had been reinforced by 500 [[musketeers]]. The Spaniards captured all the artillery (2 pieces of artillery of campaign and 4 mortars), ammunition carts, flags, equipment (over 1,000 musketry), and supplies from the enemy. King [[Philip IV of Spain]] personally congratulated the Duke of Albuquerque for the victory. On 4 December 1650, the French troops led by the [[Duke of Mercoeur]] finally capitulated to the Spanish forces commanded by the [[Franco-Spanish War (1635)|Marquis of Mortara]] at Tortosa.Coll/Muñoz pp. 226–229 == References == {{Reflist}} == Bibliography == *Israel, Jonathan. ''Conflicts of empires: Spain, the low countries and the struggle for world supremacy, 1585-1713'' Hambledon Continuum Publishing (2003) ISBN 1-85285-161-9 *{{sp icon}} Rodríguez González, Agustín Ramón. ''Victorias por mar de los Españoles''. Biblioteca de Historia. Madrid 2006. *Black, Jeremy. ''European warfare 1494-1660''. Routledge. (2002) ISBN 978-0-415-27532-3. *{{sp icon}} Sanz, Fernando Martín. ''La política internacional de Felipe IV.'' Fernando Martín Sanz. (2003) ISBN 978-987-561-039-2. *{{sp icon}} Mossèn Sanabre. ''La acción de Francia en Cataluña por la pugna de la hegemonia en Europa''. Barcelona (1956) *{{sp icon}} Castrillo González, Carmen. ''Catálogo de manuscritos de la Biblioteca Universitaria de Salamanca''. Escrito por Biblioteca Universitaria de Salamanca. *{{ca icon}} Muñoz i Sebastià, Joan Hilari/Querol Coll, Enric. ''La Guerra dels Segadors a Tortosa 1640-1651''. Romanya-Valls SA (2004) ISBN 84-9791-069-9 {{coord missing|Spain}} [[Category:Naval battles involving Spain]] [[Category:Naval battles involving France]] [[Category:Naval battles of the Franco-Spanish War (1635–59)]] [[Category:Battles of the Catalan Revolt]] [[Category:Conflicts in 1650]] [[Category:1650 in Europe]]
